captions.text: Terribly scary, it’s terrifying.
In this series of films we take you on a journey through the development...
...and creation of Efteling’s latest spectacular attraction.
In this episode we join the project team as they travel on a working trip to Germany.
We also take a look at how work is progressing on the construction site.
Has the adverse weather in recent weeks caused any delays?
And what did the project team think of their first ride on a dive coaster?
This is 'The making-of: Baron 1898'.
Around Christmas and New Year, the Baron 1898 construction site experienced snow and severe cold.
Work has recommenced in earnest at the construction site but is everything still on schedule?
We were due to work through the entire Christmas period and that’s what we did.
We have had one or two setbacks.
There were a few days on which it snowed quite heavily and we reached a virtual standstill.
But we’ve since made up for the lost time and now we’re pretty much back on schedule.
We are currently working on the tunnel beneath the new attraction.
It’s reached the stage where we are now able to stand on the concrete floor.
And we’re busy applying the brickwork to the terminal building.
We need roughly another two weeks to complete the brickwork.
And we’ve also made a start on the roofing; one roof is already watertight.
We have even made a start on the building’s interior theming.
Applying shading to the walls and ceilings and introducing the first of the smaller theme elements.
From the beginning of February we will start to see a real rollercoaster.
That’s when the track sections arrive and we make a start on constructing the tower.
That will be a significant moment for us.
The type of rollercoaster we are building is a dive coaster.
The unique thing about which is that, for a few seconds, you are suspended in mid-air above the ground.
This only serves to increase the excitement and anticipation.
The rollercoaster manufacturer we selected is B&M.
B&M, which specialises in the construction of dive coasters and has built more than 90 rollercoasters.
The company is known for its exceptional quality, of which we will make optimal use.
This rollercoaster will be unique because, as you would expect, it has a story behind it, from beginning to end.
You become part of that story from the moment you enter the queue to the moment you leave the attraction.
That’s the thing I’m most proud of; that the rollercoaster is so unique, that there’s nothing standard about it.
It’s important for us to look at other theme parks and their attractions.
To be sure we’ve selected the right supplier and the right rollercoaster ride.
That’s why we went to visit Heide Park, where we learnt a great deal.
Not only in technical terms but also on an operational level.
To gain first-hand experience of a dive coaster, the project team has taken a working trip to Germany.
This is the Krake, a B&M-built dive coaster.
The rollercoaster supplier builds the track.
But we have to put it all together and build the complete package surrounding it.
We have to build the foundations, the steel frame has to be assembled and...
...then the electrical installations need to be fitted and connected.
We work with local companies in this respect and...
...it’s good for them to see with their own eyes exactly how such a ride works.
Our terminal building is clearly almost complete but then a large section of track has to be incorporated.
That’s one of the things we’re looking at here, how to install the motor once the building is finished.
From a technical perspective, this dive coaster is unbelievably well built.
The ride is very smooth and very quiet; you can barely hear the track, just the sound of screaming people.
It is a technically very well planned and realised track and, of course, the drop is unique!
Terrifying!
As the project team returns to the Netherlands...
...people in Budapest are working hard on the construction of the lift tower.
As soon as this is completed it will be transported to Efteling.
And then it won’t be long before Kaatsheuvel’s first dive coaster ascends.
Subscribe and stay on the lookout for further episodes of 'The Making-of: Baron 1898'.

Divecoaster. Misschien dat de drop daarvan wat hoger was (overigens een 
heerlijk gevoel zo'n verticale val), maar verder dan dat was er weinig 
interessants aan. Nou was dat een prototype, maar toch. Baron 1898 krijgt 
extra toevoegingen na de drop, inversies, en de thematisering is een stuk 
mooier. Kan niet wachten. En bovendien veel dichterbij !﻿
